title: pet cats dogs transmit coronavirus humans
story: Documents published today reveal that the risk of pets spreading Covid- to humans is considered medium.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut this risk was high for those with underlying health problems or poor immune systems.The experts cautioned that there was little data available and for that reason there is a high level of uncertainty.In fact, theres a bigger risk of humans giving the virus to their pets in the first place, the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesreport says.Until more information is available on the likely infection status of a companion animal in contact with an infected SARS-CoV- patient, we consider the likelihood of exposure to be at most, medium, with a high level of uncertainty, it states. There is a strong possibility that the animal could act as a fomite for short periods of time, carrying virus on the fur, which could transfer virus to other members of the household or people in close contact. Therefore, we consider this risk of exposure also to be, at most, medium likelihood. This likelihood nevertheless is outweighed by that from other infected people in the household.The experts added: Cats and dogs are equally susceptible to the virus attaching to host cells, because of the structural similarity of the receptor protein, ACE, to the human receptor.Sage carried out a qualitative risk assessment after two dogs were infected with SARS-CoV- - the virus that causes Covid- - in Hong Kong.One was a -year-old Pomeranian and the other a German Shepherd whose owners had both contracted coronavirus.The dogs were tested on several occasions and nasal swabs were positive for the virus across repeat time points. Once the dogs had tested negative twice, they were released from quarantine but sadly the Pomeranian died two days later of unkown causes - but suspected to be due to stress.Meanwhile, a cat in Belgium also tested positive for the virus after its owner fell ill with Covid-.The cat had diarrhoea, respiratory distress and vomiting before the virus was detected in faecal samples.It prompted concerns that pets could be a route of transmission but experts concluded that the risk to Brits remained low.Sage said: There is still a considerable level of uncertainty about the roleany of companion animals in SARS-CoV- transmission. There are no surveillance data and any risk level relies on previous observations of seropositive animals in previous outbreaks, the precautionary advice from the OIE and the two cases in dogs in Hong Kong.Companion animals can have very close contact with their owners which could lead to exchange of respiratory fluid therefore, they may be exposed.Nevertheless, exposure may not lead to infectivity and infection in animals and the SARS-CoV- appears to be predominantly transmitted from human to human. Until more surveillance data are available, a precautionary risk level has been given.Reviewing the report, Prof James Wood, head of Department of Veterinary Medicine at the University of Cambridge, said:“Despite millions of people having had Covid-, the numbers of pets found to be ill or infected is still tiny. Put simply, our pet dogs and cats can catch Covid- from us, when they are living with us, but only do on very rare occasions.“The risks of owners catching Covid- because their pet dog or cat has it are very low. To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.There are more ways that a dog or cat that has been in extended contact with a Covid- patient could carry the virus on its coat into another situation, but in my view this scenario is very unlikely, particularly for dogs which tend to be less free roaming than cats.“There is no reason for vulnerable people to stop cuddling their dog or cat. Everyone should maintain good hygienic standards with their pets and wash their hands across the day, as is generally advised, to avoid the risks of them contaminating themselves.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sheep carcass panther cotswolds big cat
story: A stunned dog walked spotted a panther after the animal was found dead.Farmers are worried for their livestock after the mutilated skeleton of an ewe was discovered on a footpath last Saturday near South Cerney, Gloucestershire.Sheep farmer Francis Freeth, , had counted his flock of  the night before and received a call the next morning from a horried walker.Images show a sheeps head and not much more apart from its spinal column and some ribs.It is understood to be the second ewe to be mauled to death in the past ten days.Cops have confirmed they are investigating multiple reports of black panther sightings and said the sheep carcass was pulled over three ft tall fences and stripped away from its flock.Ellie Haggart rang police after she spotted a large feline prowling towards her as she walked her French Bulldog Oscar in the village last Thursday.It is thought the cat could be the Beast of Broadwell, which has been spotted stalking Cotswolds villages for several years.Ellie said the beast came out into full view of the footpath.The -year-old added: “I didn’t know what it was at first but I knew it was pretty big, I wanted to assume it was an extremely large dog.“I soon realised there was no owner and then I could start to see certain defining characteristics of the animal like the feline movement of the shoulders and the dference in the shape of its legs compared to that of a dog.“I don’t knowit saw Oscar and I, but it started prowling slowly in our direction. I was terried.” Gloucestershire polices rural crime team are investigating whether the sighting could be linked to the carcass of Francis dead sheep.Francis told The Sun: I checked my livestock on Friday last week and counted them all there but on Saturday morning I received a phone call from someone who was out walking and had found one of my sheep mutilated.It was disgusting, only its head was left but not much more apart from its spine and a few ribs, it had been completely stripped bare.Im quite annoyed really but theres not much you can doa beast like that is attacking your flock.Im just hoping it wont get anymore, but I wouldnt be surprisedit did as its a ready supply of food for it. Gloucestershire Polices rural crime team said: “Were looking into the report of a Black Panther sighting in the Wildmoorway Lane area of South Cerney. Officers appealed on social media with a photo of the sheep carcass and askedit was connected to the big cat sighting.The wildle crime officer added the sheep was Pulled over three stock fences ft in height from its field and stripped some distance away.A Gloucestershire Police spokeswoman said: Last Thursdaywe had a call from a woman who thought she had seen a large black cat near to Wildmoor Way, South Cerney.Two further potential sightings have been reported.A wildle crime officer has also been in contact with a farmer after a sheep carcass was found in a field in Ashton Keynes.Big cats such as panthers are capable of walking dozens of miles a day and are capable of climbing and hiding in trees which make useful hiding spots when they want to keep away from humans.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dad uses coronavirus lockdown build incredible tree house 120
story: Joe Rackley built the fab garden structure with its own slide from old wooden pallets.The Watford-based TV and film prop maker, , decided to use the extra time at home to build a hideaway cabin for Tabitha, three, and three-month-old Rosa.He said: It’s almost entirely made from free scavenged pallets - all of which I had permission to take - apart from a few bits of random wood I had behind my shed.“It had to be extremely low budget as the industry I work in completely stopped due to the pandemic.The challenge of seriously limited money was a minor hurdle though, as Joe rarely opened his wallet - using stored old tins of paints and boxes of screws.Luckily he had slides bought in a closing down sale in , which meant hehad to just fork out for a few things such as plastic roof covering for £, and cork flooring for £.Joe described it as a lockdown project for sure. I had no plans or drawings, so I made it up as I went along. It actually started in a dferent place in the garden but when I’d made the  decking bit, decided to move it.The structure has two rooms: one main room for his children to play in and a fairy door as well as a treehouse. Unsurprisingly it turned out to be a big hit with his toddler, who thinks it’s absolute heaven.“I wanted something to pass the time and obviously a Wendy house for the kids would be good for them too,” Joe said.But, he joked, there was another reason for spending so much time pottering around outside - it meant he avoided changing nappies for three months.As luck would have it, pals chipped in with old rubbish lying around too.My neighbour Caine had a big box of screws he donated the windows are polycarbonate and donated from my friend Mike who had some material lying around in his garage.“My dad had the pole that holds up the tree house for years in his garden - he poached it from his local park when the council updated the kids’ playground.“He also pulled the little ladder out from his stash which was apparently mine from my childhood bunk bed, Joe said.His Instagram followers, who have been following him throughout his journey via @joe__rackley have given it the thumbs-up.Joe said: “Just have a go, it doesn’t matter what your skill level is, just be creative and make something.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids gcses return school monday
story: THOUSANDS more kids studying for next years GCSEs and A-levels will be able toto school from Monday.Almost nine in ten secondaries and colleges are set to reopen their doors to Year  and  pupils, according to a survey. The Association of School and College Leaderssaid the move would be the latest in the rollback of lockdown measures.It follows the reopening of many primary schools to reception, Year , and Year  pupils at the start of the month.Government guidance says no more than a quarter of secondary school students should be on site at any one time.Most are planning to bring back face-to-face contact with all pupils, except those who are shielding, at least once a week.But a quarter wont welcome back all eligible children because of parents worried about the virus.The survey of  heads also found some will put back reopening until at least June  due to concerns over local infection rates.ASCL general secretary Geoff Barton said schools had moved mountains to stay open during the pandemic and get kids back into the classroom.He said: “This is akin to something between a military operation and an exercise in mathematics.There are many practical safety measures to put in place, as well as allocating small groups of eligible pupils to available teachers, while ensuring no more than a quarter of the cohort is on site at any time. “School and college staff deserve great credit for all they have done over the past few months, and all they are doing now.Mr Barton said ministers now need to come forward with a national recovery plan that lays out how schools will operate for the next academic year.He said: “It is essential that this plan is developed as soon as possible in order to give schools and colleges time to prepare for this vital title: pubs ban singing shouting reopen halt coronavirus spread
story: In order to relax the two-metre social distancing rule, boozers could be forced to switch loud music off so customers dont have to shout or talk loudly, which sprays the virus further.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt is just one of many measures being discussed by Whitehall sources to help pubs and restaurants on their , which is reported to be early next month.Pubs, restaurants and shops could be allowed to ignore the two-metre distancing rule as part of a major blueprint for getting Britain back up and running.Businesses will be able to allow staff and workers closer together but onlythey can show they have taken measures to lower the risk of catching coronavirus.Offices, bistros and shopping centres would be expected to prove they’ve made spaces safe for customers and staff before being given the green light to open their doors again.It could mean bustling businesses bounce back eventhe two metre rule stays in place for longer than expected - although yesterday Boris Johnson hinted he could shrink the distances to one.Whitehall sources working on the proposal suggest firms may be allowed to reopenthey can demonstrate they have taken measures to mitigate risks.Papers drawn up by the government’s scientic advisors, and released yesterday, outline a raft of possible options to help kickstart the economy.They include " rel"noreferrer noopener"staggering working hours, working in smaller groups, video conferencing and increased cleaning.Other ideas include the use of antimicrobial surfaces, replacing door handles with sensors and click and collect instead of waiting staff.People will be encouraged to put the toilet seat down, move around in one direction, avoid hot desking and sit back to back with colleagues.A source said: “People would have to do some kind of risk assessment as to what the likelihood of being exposed to the virus is.“There are ious mitigations including say ventilation, screens and barriers, face coverings, cleaning, hygiene.“Theres a whole raft of measures that could potentially be used - some are more useful than others." rel"noreferrer noopener"Pressure has been mounting on the PM to reduce the two metre rule, which many fear will cripple industry amid the worst economic crash the nation has ever seen.Sir Patrick Vallance said earlier this week that the measurement was a guide based on risk, rather than a rule.But now sources close to advisers stress a review of the two metre guidelines would be a policy review, led by ministers, rather than a scientic review.A Whitehall source added: “The scientists don’t regard two metres as a rule - it’s a guide.They give the evidence as they know it and then it’s a policy decision. It’s a judgement call about probability.”But yesterday, the Prime Minister hinted he was listening to the scientists, and the distance was being reviewed right now.He said: “We are looking for the moment where we have got the figures down, but when they are down so far, we can say the two metre rule is no longer necessary.“We are doing a review right now - keeping it under review - and obviously as we make further progress, I hope to say more.” Figures released by the Office for National Statistics show the infection rate in the community is low with only around six people infected for every  person. And the Sage group revealed yesterday that " rel"noreferrer noopener"The R rate was at or below  - and therefore not easily spreading - across most of the UK.The PM added: “The vast proportion, probably  per cent of infections ,are in care homes or infections in the NHS.“There are complex issues about the risks the whole of the community faces with the R.“The crucial thing is the overall rate of infections we are seeing, the overall rate of infections in the country or community and the overall rate of new hospital admissions.” As the PM faces increased pressure to drop the distance, Scotland Minister Mr Jack called for the move to one metre distancing.He said: As soon as it is possible to do so with the R number suppressed, I would like to see it move to one metre.I think, to get back to something to near normal in the way that we conduct our lives and our businesses, as we see the virus recede, and weve seen this happen without any bad consequences in other European countries, we should move to one metre when the time is right.” Yesterday " rel"noreferrer noopener"pub groups urged the Government to confirm a date when they can reopen along with the safety guidelines.The British Beer  Pub Associationsaid the Governments road map indicates pubs will be able to reopen from July  - story: They were blasted into space onboard a Falcon  rocket from Cape Canaveral in Florida in the US.⚠️ Watch our YouTube live stream of the launchThe mission originally appeared to be scheduled for June  at :am ET but was pushed back.As of yet, neither Nasa nor Space X have revealed why the launch was rescheduled.The Nasa Kennedy Space Center website states: This will be the th mission in support of the constellation of networked satellites known as Starlink.The goal of Starlink is to create a network that will help provide internet services to those who are not yet connected, and to provide reliable and affordable internet across the globe.If you want to see Starlink satellites in the sky with your own eyes then try visiting the Find Starlink websiteand enter your location.Good visibility and quite a few sightings are expected across the UK over the weekend.Not sure where to look  Your phones got you covered.There are a number of stargazing apps you can use to follow the path of Starlink probes.On the Apple App Store, wed recommend Night Sky, which is free and helps you find all kinds of celestial wonders.For Android fans, Satellite Tracker should do the trick on iPhone.Simply head outside at one of the scheduled Starlink times above, load up one of the apps and you should be able to spot one.Starlink is a controversial scheme that aims to beam Wi-Fi to people from space using a mega constellation of thousands of satellites.“With performance that far surpasses that of traditional satellite internet ... Starlink will deliver high speed broadband internet to locations where access has been unreliable, expensive, or completely unavailable,” the official website explains.The project is the brainchild of tech billionaire Musk, whose Calornia-based rocket firm SpaceX builds and operates the satellites.More than  have been launched so far, with the network eventually set to reach ,, rising to as many as , in the future.SpaceX typically sends its satellites up in batches of  at a time. Each group is launched atop an unmanned Falcon  rocket built by SpaceX.The solar-powered tech typically orbits around  miles above Earth.How the probes will affect the night sky is causing concern as they sit in a low orbit, so appear brighter than stars and planets.The Starlink programme is controversial among astronomers, who have slammed Musks scheme.They say Starlink gets in the way of observations due to light reflected off the the satellites.University of Western Ontario meteor researcher Denis Vida stated in a blog post last year: One has to be concerned how will our skies look like when hearing that there are plans to launch a total of , satellites.This might completely deny us to do any optical meteor observations as soon as .Musk has hit back at his critics, claiming the satellites have no such impact.Speaking at a conference in Washington DC last month, he said: I am confident that we will not cause any impact whatsoever in astronomical discoveries. the transmission of the virus across the country.The R rate should be . or below before thinking about introducing a bubbling strategy, it warned.During a meeting of SAGE on May , the experts concluded: SAGE advised that social bubbles have the potential to create unwanted effects and advised against their introduction in the short term, when other social distancing measures have only just been lted.The group of scientic experts who advise the Government has warned against making too many changes at the same time.Next week shops are due to reopen across England, and some secondary school children will go back for contact time with their teachers.Any bubbling will increase infection risk, the minutes warned.If introduced, bubbling should only happen when it is safe to do so from an epidemiological perspective and on a very modest basis initially.The smaller the household, the smaller the risk of more infection spreading, the advice said.And breaking the rules around bubbling - title: non essential shops hope return
story: NewsNon-essential shops hope for theof shoppers after losing £.bn a weekStore bosses are desperate to welcome back customers as fears are growing that a nation now used to shopping online may never be won back to High Streets and shopping mallsShareCommentsByStephen Hayward:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsCan even Regent Street in London ever recover  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHigh street stores will nervously open their doors tomorrow for the first time in three months – ­praying for a post-lockdown spending spree to avert disaster. Bosses are desperate to welcome back customers after losing £.billion a WEEK in sales during the shutdown of non-essential shops. But there’s an uncomfortable sense of boom or bust surrounding a day that may make or break a retail revival. Fears are growing that a nation now used to shopping online may never be won back to malls and precincts in numbers needed to spark a recovery. And there are serious worries for the future of a string of top names already teetering on the brink BEFORE Covid- hit our shores. All this just days after latest figures showed the British economy shrank by a fth in April – its biggest ever fall and twice as bad a dip as the s Winter of Discontent. Now we are in a summer of apprehension, with retailers needing a flood of bargain-hunting customers – only to face a controlled trickle under guidelines to keep everyone safe. Fashion chains forced to close by the virus are sitting on £billion of unsold stock and retailers including Next and Gap are offering cut-price deals to get shoppers spending again. But experts warn there could be chaotic queues outside many stores forced to limit shopper numbers to abide by the two-metre social distancing rule. And yesterday retail analyst Richard Hyman cautioned that any bounceback could be short-lived.  He said: “Superficially, it’s very compelling to say that we’ve all been stuck at home for months and we’re going to rush out to the shops. “But as long as social distancing is in place, shops are not going to make any money. Pavements are not that deep, where’s the queue going to go  “It’s nightmarish. It’s going to be virtually impossible for bricks and mortar retailers to avoid losses with social distancing. A cut to one metre will make it easier, but it won’t turn economic losses into gains. Retailers are desperate to turn stock into cash. “Butyour costs are up because you have to provide anti-virus screens, hand sanitiser and PPE for staff – andyour footfall is reduced – the numbers don’t stack up unless you charge people more.”  Helen Dickinson of the British Retail Consortium offered little more hope of an instant recovery. “The Government’s support – from its job retention scheme to loan guarantees and business rates holiday – has provided a vital leline, but more will be needed,” she said. “Many retailers are struggling to pay rent. Without more government intervention, many shops, large and small, will be forced out of business – leaving high streets and shopping centres empty.” Mothercare went bust in January while Debenhams, House of Fraser and Marks  Spencer all closed branches before the crisis.  Other retailers, including Topshop owner Arcadia, New Look, Carpetright and Homebase have been forced to seek legal agreements with landlords to shut stores and slash their rent bills to stave off insolvency. Joshua Bamfield of the Centre for Retail Research reckons some chains will stagger their branch reopenings. He said: “Many will want to see how this is going to work – not only from a profit and loss point of view but with social distancing too. They’ll wait to seethe Government gives in to calls to reduce it to one metre.  “The next couple of months will be key in terms of who survives. If firms have two quarters where revenues are very small and losses mount, they’ll have to do something about it, which may be closure given many were operating with signicant losses in .” The British Retail Consortium has drawn up a five-point guide for shoppers, backed by  chain stores, to avoid a new wave of infections. It urges us to queue sensibly, maintain social distancing, follow instructions inside and outside, stick to hygiene rules and respect shop staff.

story: NewsBritain behind boards: The statues being covered up from Churchill to Nelson MandelaFrom Winston Churchill to Nelson Mandela, monuments across the UK are being covered up over fears they will be targeted by both anti-racism and far-right protesters, as Black Lives Matter marches follow the death of George Floyd for a third weekend runningShareCommentsByAnna MacSwan:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsWartime Prime Minister Winston Churchills statue has been boarded up " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailStatues and war memorials across the UK are being boarded up over fears they could be targeted. From Winston Churchill to Nelson Mandela, it is feared the monuments will be targeted by either anti-racism or far-right protesters as Brits take to the streets following the death of George Floyd for a third weekend running. Mayor of London Sadiq Khan is warning people to stay at home for fear of violence sparked by far-right counter demonstrations, and ongoing coronavirus infection concerns. Police have imposed some strict guidelines, including a pm curfew cut-off time for the protests. In wake of unarmed black man Mr Floydaposs death in police custody in Minneapolis, Black Lives Matter protesters have rallied worldwide, calling for an end to racial injustices. The vast majority of people demonstrating have done so peacefully. Last weekend, protesters in Bristol captured headlines around the world last Friday when they tore down a statue of slave trader Edward Colston and threw it into the harbour. On the same day, a statue of Churchill in Parliament Square was defaced with graffiti claming he was racist. Now, amid fears of clashes between Black Lives Matter protesters and far-right groups, a number of key statues have been put in protective boxes. It comes after the Democratic Football Lads Alliance called on its supporters to descend on the capital to protect monuments. Here, we list some of the statues which have been covered up out of fear they will become targets - albeit for a iety of reasons.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email Winston Churchill  Former Prime Minister Winston Churchill is best known for leading Britain to victory in World War Two. The Conservative politician is described on the governmentaposs website as an inspirational statesman, writer, orator and leader. But critics have pointed to his views on race and imperialism, and he is known to have described Britainaposs empire as being for the good of the primitive and subject races. He also opposed Indian independence. Ahead of planned protests in London this weekend his statue has been covered with protective boards. The move has been described by Boris Johnson as absurd and shameful. The Prime Minister says that although Churchill held some views that would be unacceptable today, he saved the country from fascist and racist tyranny. Cenotaph  Part of the official war memorial to Britainaposs war dead, which stands in Whitehall, has also been hidden from view. It comes after the monument was defaced, along with Churchillaposs statue, during last weekaposs Black Lives Matter march. Graffiti with the letters BLM was sprayed on the base of the memorial, where wreaths are laid on Remembrance Sunday each year. It has now been boarded up to protect it from further vandalism, and Mr Johnson has urged protesters not to turn out this weekend. A growing minority unfortunately have hijacked them and they are using them as a pretext to attack the police to cause violence and to cause damage to public property, he said. My message to everybody is for all sorts of reasons, they should not go. You should not have a situation where people who are protesting on one basis are violently attacking the police and public property. Robert Baden-Powell  A statue of Scouts founder Robert Baden-Powell has long stood in Poole Quay, Dorset. The monument was scheduled to be put into storage on Thursday due to concerns about Baden-Powellaposs associations with the Nazis and the Hitler Youth. But the removal was delayed after a crowd of people - some wearing Scout unorms - gathered around the statue and vowed to protect it. It comes after a petition calling for the memorial in Poole Quay to stay in place gained more than , signatures. Mark Howell, deputy leader of Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole Council said many felt that removing the status would be giving in to protesters. Guyaposs and St Thomasaposs Hospital Trust has confirmed that it will be taking down a statue of its founder, who had links to the slave trade. Workmen placed  of wood around the structure on Thursday. Guy - who founded the London hospital in  - amassed a fortune of £,as a shareholder in the slave-trading firm South Sea Company. A statement from Guyaposs and St Thomasapos Charity, Guyaposs and St Thomasapos NHS Foundation Trust, and Kingaposs College London, said: Like many organisations in Britain, we know that we have a duty to address the legacy of colonialism, racism and slavery in our work. We absolutely recognise the public hurt and anger that is generated by the symbolism of public statues of historical figures associated with the slave trade in some way. We have therefore decided to remove statues of Robert Clayton and Thomas Guy from public view, and we look forward to engaging with and receiving guidance from the Mayor of Londonaposs Commission on each. We see the pervasive and harmful effects of structural racism every day through our work. Black people have worse health outcomes, and this inequality is one of many ways racism permeates our society. We are fully committed to tackling racism, discrimination and inequality, and we stand in solidarity with our patients, students, colleagues and communities. Nelson Mandela  Mayor of London Sadiq Khan instructed Nelson Mandelaaposs statue in Parliament Square to be covered. The monument has stood in honour of the anti-apartheid leader, who was President of South Africa from  to , since . The countryaposs first black head of state, Mandela was imprisoned for  years on Robben Island while fighting to end institutionalised racial segregation. The move comes amid fear of counter protests from extreme far-right groups this weekend. Mr Khan said: Iaposm extremely concerned that further protests in central London not only risk spreading Covid-, but could lead to disorder, vandalism and violence. Extreme far-right groups who advocate hatred and ision are planning counter-protests, which means that the risk of disorder is high. Be in no doubt these counter-protests are there to provoke violence, and their only goal is to distract and hijack this important issue. Staying home and ignoring them is the best response this weekend. Mahatma Gandhi  Along with Churchill and Mandela, a statue of Indian independence leader Mahatma Ghandi is also being boarded up in Parliament Square. Gandhi, famous for his role in securing Indiaaposs independence through nonviolent protest, is widely considered the father of his country. But there have been calls to remove a number of his monuments in the UK, as campaigners accused him of aposracismapos. A bronze statue was unveiled in Leicester in  and a third was put up in Manchester in  despite objections. A petition against the Leicester statue describes Gandhi as a fascist, racist and sexual predator who has brought inconsolable suffering. Robert Peel  Authorities have also decided to protect keep a statue of Sir Robert Peel in Tamworth, Birmingham - but this time over fears it might be confused with another. The memorial appeared on a website called ‘Topple the Racists’, which maps statues of historic figures whom it opposes. Peel actually served as a minister in the Government which made slave trading an offence. Danny Cook, leader of Tamworth Borough Council, said: “Given the current national focus on memorials, including statues of Robert Peel, we feel it necessary to take extra precautions to protect Tamworth’s -year-old Peel monument for the time being and fence it off.

story: NewsCuddling pet cats or dog may put you at risk of catching coronavirus, SAGE warnsA SAGE report states that the risk of pets transmitting the virus to humans is medium - although the risk was high for those with underlying health problems or poor immune systemsShareCommentsByRachel Endley :,  JUN NewsA report from SAGE states that the risk of pets transmitting the virus to humans is medium - although the risk was high for those with underlying health problems or poor immune systems " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Experts from SAGE have warned that cats and dogs can transmit coronavirus to humans via their fur.The warning comes from the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , which has been providing the latest scientic advice to the government during the covid- pandemic. The report states that the risk of pets transmitting the virus to humans is aposmediumapos - although the risk was aposhighapos for those with underlying health problems or poor immune systems. SAGE carried out a risk assessment after two dogs were infected with the virus in Hong Kong and a cat in Belgium also tested positive after its owner fell ill with Covid-. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here  After looking into the risks, SAGE reported that there was a high level of uncertainty in a link with pets passing the virus to humans.The report states: Until more information is available on the likely infection status of a companion animal in contact with an infected SARS-CoV- patient, we consider the likelihood of exposure to be at most, medium, with a high level of uncertainty. There is still a considerable level of uncertainty about the roleany of companion animals in SARS-CoV- transmission. There are no surveillance data and any risk level relies on previous observations of seropositive animals in previous outbreaks, the precautionary advice from the OIE and the two cases in dogs in Hong Kong.  Companion animals can have very close contact with their owners which could lead to exchange of respiratory fluid therefore, they may be exposed. Nevertheless, exposure may not lead to infectivity and infection in animals and the SARS-CoV- appears to be predominantly transmitted from human to human. Until more surveillance data are available, a precautionary risk level has been given. While a link has been found SAGE said there was actually a bigger risk of humans giving the virus to their pets in the first place. In response to the report Professor James Wood, Head of Department of Veterinary Medicine, and researcher in Infection dynamics and control of diseases, University of Cambridge, said : The paper reiterates what we know, which is that despite millions of people having had COVID, the numbers of pets found to be ill or infected is still tiny.Put simply, our pet dogs and cats can catch COVID from us, when they are living with us, but only do on very rare occasions. “The paper also looks into the risks of pets transmitting COVID to owners and findsthat the risks of owners catching COVID because their pet dog or cat has it are very low.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCoronavirus social aposbubblesapos will start today, enabling some people to visit other households for the first time in months. It comes after scientists advised against bubbles being introduced as they could create apossignicant unwanted effectsapos. However, the Government decided that from today, people living alone in England can form bubbles with another household. Northern Ireland is adopting a similar relaxation of the regulations for people living alone. In a report of its meeting on May , published yesterday, the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesadvised strong caution to introducing social bubbling and said it could not be seen as a universal good. But the SAGE report said that while larger households social bubbling together posed a signicant potential risk, bubbling may be appropriate in limited circumstances. How the social aposbubblesapos will work Who is covered by the new arrangements  Adults living alone or single parents living with children under the age of . What will they be able to do that they could not before  They can form a bubble with one other household which means they will effectively be treated as a single household for the purpose of the lockdown rules. That means they can visit each other indoors in their homes - staying overnightthey wish - and they will not have to observe the two-metre social-distancing rule. These bubbles are strictly exclusive - neither household can form a bubble with anyone .  Who might benefit Elderly people living alone could form a bubble with the household of an adult son or daughter enabling them to visit and even hug their grandchildren for the first time since lockdown. Single parents could pair up with their own parents allowing them to share childcare duties and reuniting grandparents and grandchildren. Couples who do not live together will be able to visit and to stay with each other. If one half of a couple shares a flat or house with one or more other people, they can see their partner as long they live alone -their partner also shares a home they cannot see each other. Andseveral people share a flat or house and all have partners who live alone, only one will be able to see their partner, which could lead to some interesting conversations. This will affect large numbers of young people living in towns and cities.  What about households where both grandparents are still living - can they now visit their children and grandchildren  At this stage onlytheir son or daughter is the only adult in the other household in the bubble. Andthe grandparents have two or more children who live alone, they will have to choose between them. Downing Street has acknowledged not everyone will benefit from the change although officials have hinted a further loosening of the rulesthe coronavirus outbreak continues to decline. Can households form more than one bubble  No. The arrangement must be exclusive with no switching of bubble partners. Will people have to formally register these bubble arrangements  No, it will be taken on trust. No  says the public has shown great responsibility in following the social distancing rules so far. Is there any limit on the distance between households in a bubble  Again no, although officials are suggesting people should try to stay local where possible.  What about vulnerable people who are shielding due to their age or health problems  At the moment, officials say it is too soon for them to be able to join support bubbles. What about parents who are separated but who currently share childcare with the children moving between the two households  That will continue. If the parents are the only adult in the household they can form a bubble with another household - meaning the children could potentially be in two bubbles, one for each parent. What happenssomeone in a bubble develops coronavirus symptoms  All members of both households in the bubble must self-isolate for  days. Does this apply only to England A scheme in Northern Ireland has also been brought in from Saturday. This is for a person who lives alone, and can visit someone aposs private dwelling, including staying one or more nights. If they have a child or children living with them they do not qualy. This will be be reviewed on Monday.  What do the scientists say  A SAGE report of its meeting on May  said: Sage advised that social bubbles have the potential to create signicant unwanted effects and advised against their introduction in the short term, when other distancing measures have only just been lted or in conjunction with release of other measures. Sage advised strong caution concerning the introduction of social bubbling - particularly in the short term, when other distancing measures have only just been lted or in conjunction with release of other measures. Sage has advised previously against making too many changes at once. Sage concluded that bubbling may be appropriate in limited circumstances. The report was published a day before adults living alone or single parents in England will be allowed to mix with one other household. Further reports to SAGE, also published on Friday, warned that breaching support bubbles could lead to a signicant risk of increasing transmission.

title: man urinates next pc keith
story: NewsFury as yob urinates next to PC Keith Palmer memorial during far-right protestPC Keith Palmer was killed by Islamist terrorist Khalid Masood in the grounds of Parliament in central London in  - and a photo showing a man urinating next to his memorial has outraged the MP who tried to save his leShareByChris KitchingSenior News ReporterJess GlassTaz Ali:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsA man urinates next to the memorial to PC Keith Palmer " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA man urinated next to a memorial to PC Keith Palmer, the officer killed in the Westminster terror attack, as far-right protesters ran riot in central London. The picture - taken amid violent clashes between far-right protesters and police - has sparked widespread outrage, a campaign to identy the man dubbed an embarrassment to Britain, and calls for him to be sent to prison. It happened as hooligans and far-right groups claimed they were there to protect statues and memorials. An investigation has been launched by the politan Police. MP Tobias Ellwood, who gave first aid to PC Palmer as he lay dying after being stabbed to death in the grounds Parliament by Islamist terrorist Khalid Masood in , said the image of the man urinating next to the memorial was abhorrent. The Tory MP for Bournemouth East and chairman of the Defence Select Committee, tweeted a picture of the man and wrote: Absolute shame on this man. Click here to follow our live blog with the latest updates from the violent clashes in central London. Of all the images to emerge over these few testing days I find this one of most abhorrent. Please help identy him. Mr Ellwood later told Sky News:is an embarrassment to Britain. In an interview with the BBC, he said the man should come forward and apologise, adding that he was disgusted and the image was one of the most disturbing he has seen. Mr Ellwood said: We are going through a very dficult period of self-reflection here, quite rightly for us to look back and have a long overdue debate of our complex past and perhaps be more aware and critical of our own history. He added: But the minority far-right groups wanting to come to London on the pretext of defending monuments, and yet we see monuments such as this being treated in this way, shows how far this generation still has to go.  When asked whether he thought the urinating man may not have noticed the memorial, Mr Ellwood said: I donapost agree with that at all. This is the gates of Westminster, the most iconic symbol of democracy in the world next to a monument for Pc Keith Palmer. He was fully aware of what he was doing, he should step forward and apologise. These images are seen across the world, they will damage Britainaposs reputation. It will make us look like we are not in control. He agreed with the Home Secretaryaposs comments of using the full force of the law against the unruly protesters, adding: We must absolutely be firm on these people who choose to come to London and defend these statues but actually come here on the pretext of attacking the police and pursuing other agendas. Commander Bas Javid, of politan Police, said the force has launched an investigation. He said: “We are aware of a disgusting and abhorrent image circulating on social media of a man appearing to urinate on a memorial to PC Palmer. “I feel for PC Palmer’s family, friends, and colleagues. “We have immediately launched an investigation, and will gather all the evidence available to us and take appropriate action.” The politan Police Federation chairman, Ken Marsh, condemned the disorder and unruliness, and suggested the man pictured urinating next to the memorial should be sent to prison.  He said: Itaposs horrendous. The man urinating next to Keith Palmeraposs memorial is disgusting. A faction of people today [Saturday] only had one intention - to be violent and unlawful, they didnapost come here to protect the statues, itaposs just disorder and unruliness. I suggest serious custodial sentences in relation to assaults on police and others, criminal damage and urinating next to the memorial of heroes. Senior Tory MP Rob Halfon described the behaviour of a protester seen urinating by the memorial to PC Palmer as “horric”.  Mr Halfon, the chair of the Commons Education Committee, said he hoped the perpetrator was tracked down and jailed. “This is just so horric. I hope they find this inidual and lock them up and throw away the key,” he said. “This is not the kind of country we are. I feel every possible good wish to the family of PC Palmer, who did so much to keep us safe.” Scotland Yard said that as of pm on Saturday, they had arrested five people for offences including violent disorder, assault on police, possession of an offensive weapon, being drunk and disorderly and possession of Class A drugs. Several hundred demonstrators, mostly white men, attended the protest organised by far-right groups, including Britain First, which claimed they wanted to protect statues such as Winston Churchill from vandalism. But fights erupted in areas near the Houses of Parliament and Trafalgar Square, as demonstrators repeatedly assailed officers with foul-mouthed chants and missiles, smoke grenades and flares. Shards of glass were strewn along the streets close to the Cenotaph on Whitehall after bottles were thrown at police officers clad in riot gear.  The violent scenes are in contrast with peaceful demonstrations that took place at Hyde Park and Marble Arch by anti-racism protesters in support of the Black Lives Mattermovement. On Friday, statues in Parliament Square - including of Winston Churchill, Nelson Mandela and Mahatma Gandhi - were boarded up to prevent them being targeted by protesters both from the Black Lives Matter movement and far-right groups. The politan Police warned people joining demonstrations on Saturday that they must be off the streets by pm or risk being arrested. At around pm, the crowd in Parliament Square thinned out after one of the exits was opened, although a few hundred people remained in the area ahead of the pm deadline. The violence has been condemned by the Mayor of London Sadiq Khan and Home Secretary Priti Patel, with the latter branding it as thoroughly unacceptable thuggery.

title: prince harry opens up over
story: NewsPrince Harry opens up over death of mum Princess Diana with terror attack survivorOwen Richards was  when his brother, uncle and grandfather were shot dead in a massacre in which  tourists died five years ago this monthShareCommentsByGeraldine McKelvieLinda Aitchison:,  JUN NewsPrince Harry with Suzanne Richards and Owen Richards at a dedication ceremony in Cannon Hill Park, Birmingham in  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email One of the youngest survivors of the  Tunisia terror attack has told how Prince Harry helped him deal with his grief after three of his family members were killed.Owen Richards was  when his brother, uncle and grandfather were shot dead in a massacre in which  tourists died five years ago this month. He cradled grandad Pat Evans, , in his dying moments and was praised by a coroner for his “extraordinary courage” in trying to save him. Last year Owen met the Duke of Sussex at the unveiling of a monument to the victims in Birmingham. It was an emotional moment he will never forget. Speaking about it for the first time with mum Suzanne Richards, Owen, now , says: “He gave me some advice. “He said I must talk about what happened. He said he knew personally, because when he lost his mum, he didn’t. It was a bit weird when he said, ‘when my mum was killed’, because she’s not just any mum – she’s Princess Diana. It seemed like he was trying to give some advice rather than have a meaningless conversation.” Owen got chatting to the Prince after giving a speech at the unveiling. He said: “I was nervous but Harry nodded during my speech. Mum and I had a teddy from our charity Smile for Joel – named after my brother – which we gave to him for his we who was pregnant.“I told him I was there when it happened and how I lost my brother, my grandad and my uncle.” Owen’s le changed forever when a celebration trip for finishing his GCSEs turned into a terrying nightmare. He was staying at the five-star Riu Imperial Marhaba Hotel in Port El Kantaoui with Joel, , uncle Adrian Evans, , and grandad Pat. They had nicknamed the trip the Jolly Boys’ Outing – after their favourite episode of sitcom Only Fools and Horses.Owen recalls texting his mum that they had got there safely and next morning the family relaxed by the pool. But less than  hours later crazed gunman Seeddine Rezgui, a -year-old Tunisian student, walked into their lives and opened fire. What followed next still remains a blur. Sports science graduate Owen finds it painful to recall the horrors that unfolded on June , . The four men tried to run inside the hotel complex to escape, but Pat fell over several times.  Owen was hugging his grandad on the floor when he was shot for the first time. Pat said: “He got me.” Owen, who himself was shot in the arm, urged him to play dead but the gunman fired again at Pat, a retired Justice of the Peace. Owen crawled along the floor to find his brother, tipped to be a future Premier League referee, and his uncle, a gas services manager, both leless in pools of blood. Shocked Owen later called mum Suzanne, , from the hospital and blurted out: “They’re all dead.” College lecturer Suzanne, who was at home in Wednesbury, West Mids, said: “All I could hear was screaming after that. Then the line fell silent. My knees buckled and I fell to the floor. My phone started pinging with messages telling me to switch on the news.  “An image of Owen flashed up – he was getting out of an ambulance. I was shaking like a leaf and in deep shock.” Owen, who had been shot in the arm, rang again and said: “I want to come home, Mum.” Suzanne had to break the devastating news to her mum Maureen, . She said: “She was on her knees, heartbroken. I just had to get to Owen. I still had hope the others were alive because you just don’t want to believe it.” Suzanne and a friend boarded a special flight chartered to pick up survivors andthem home – and the pair found they were the only ones aboard. They dashed to the hospital to find Owen on a bed in his swim shorts. Suzanne said: “I wrapped him in a hug and sobbed. I said, ‘I’m here. You’re safe now’. He looked broken.”  When Owen was discharged they were taken to a morgue where they were shown photographs of the victims. Suzanne’s worst fears were confirmed when Joel, Adrian and Pat’s pictures were there. She said: “I kept Owen in the other room, he’d been through enough. Seeing the pictures was horrendous.” A few days later, the three bodies were flown to military base Brize Norton in Oxfordshire. More than , people attended a joint funeral on July . Hundreds of tributes were also left outside Walsall FC’s Bescot Stadium, where the family had season tickets. Owen said: “The funeral was a really dficult day.”  It turned out he passed his GCSEs with flying colours on the same day, Suzanne said: “The three people he wanted to show his grades to weren’t there. They would have been so proud of him.” Owen and his mum had therapy but stopped because the sessions were “like picking at a scab”. They faced further heartache when Maureen died in , having never recovered from the trauma. The beloved family dog Max also died, lost without his owner Pat. But Owen said: “Memories come back every day. The other day I was cleaning my car and I thought of Ade, because we were both mad about cars. “I miss staying up at night watching comedies with Joel, and Mum telling us to be quiet. It’s the little things that hurt. Joel was really into Game of Thrones and I feel sad he didn’t get to see how it ended.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Queen’s official birthday was marked at Windsor Castle yesterdayfor the first time in her -year reign. In her first live public engagement during the coronavirus lockdown, the monarch attended a parade by  socially distanced soldiers from the st Battalion Welsh Guards - including the first ever female guardsman to parade for the Queen’s birthday. Wearing a floral silk jade grey and dusty pink dress by Stewart Parvin outfit and hat by Rachel Trevor-Morgan, with the diamond leek brooch of the Welsh Guards, the Queen smiled broadly as she emerged onto the historic castle’s Quadrangle from the Sovereign’s Gate. Taking her seat on a dais, a raised  decorated with pink begonias and bay trees, Her Majesty looked on with pride at the assembled military outfit, accompanied by Vice-Admiral Tony Johnstone-Burt, Master of the Household, Lt Col Michael Vernon, Comptroller and Major Nana Twemasi-Ankrah, the Queen’s equerry. It is understood that other senior members of the royal family, including the Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge tuned in on the BBC to watch the spectacle from their homes in Birkhall, Aberdeenshire and Anmer Hall, Norfolk, respectively The Queen, , was greeted by a royal salute before watching military drills by the guardsmen who are used to standing shoulder-to-shoulder, but had specially adapted their manoeuvres to keep . metres apart, under the watchful eye of Lieutenant Colonel Henry Llewelyn-Usher, who commanded the ceremony.  The st Battalion Welsh Guards, who are currently on guard at Windsor Castle and have played a key role in the Covid- response, were due to have their Colour “trooped” at this year’s official birthday parade, Trooping the Colour, which traditionally takes place at Horse Guards Parade in London and involves more than  soldiers and  horses. Soldiers were chosen to take part who were either living in the Windsor area, on duty at the Castle or based in the nearby barracks, limiting the amount of travel required. Members of the public had been actively discouraged from travelling to Windsor so that the strict rules surrounding gatherings could still be adhered to. The Queen has previously attended Trooping the Colour at Horse Guards Parade during every year of her reign, except for  when it was cancelled due to a national rail strike.Today was the first time the sovereign’s birthday parade has been held at Windsor since  during the reign of Queen Victoria. Trooping the Colour has marked the official birthday of the sovereign since . A reduced Massed Band of the Household Division of  musicians, conducted by Lieutenant Colonel Simon Hoare played a series of Welsh tunes during the brief -minute ceremony including Men of Harlech and The Rising of the Lark. Trooping in slow and quick time, band members executed “feathering” at each end to ensure they maintained social distancing.  The Queen watched the Guards’ Colour being paraded and a second salute before departing. The event was televised live on the BBC, but took place entirely within the confines of Windsor Castle, with no viewing positions for the public due to coronavirus restrictions. A royal source said the Queen was “delighted” the spectacle was performed and “grateful” for the efforts of everyone who made it a reality. Garrison Sergeant Major Warrant Officer Class  Andrew Stokes, who oversaw the soldiers’ training for the unique ceremony, said: “The Army teaches iniduals many skills, but one of the greatest is teamwork, and this parade is a marvellous display of that: a collaboration of ideas and new thinking to celebrate the leadership of the Sovereign on her official birthday. With fewer people on parade there is no hiding place, there never is, and only the highest standard is acceptable, but more spacing between iniduals means there is also no room for errors, and so the soldier has to really concentrate on their own personal drill, reaction to orders, dressing and social distancing.” Guardsman Rhian Morgan from Newport, South Wales, is one of two female Guardsmen who joined the Welsh Guards earlier this year.She is the first female Guardsman to appear on a parade for The Queen’s birthday, although she has done several duties as Queen’s Guard at the Royal Palaces and was also involved in COVID- testing at Regional Testing Centre Chessington early in the pandemic.Women regularly appear on the Trooping of the Colour as musicians, members of The King’s Troop Royal Horse Artillery, supporting staff, veterinary officers, signallers and latterly in the Household Cavalry.

Claire-Louise Colquhoun, , desperately wanted to modernise the drab, beige kitchen of her three-bed home on a budget. The legal assistant from Ayrshire, Scotland, searched the internet for materials and DIY hacks and was able to complete the project in just one week for £. And the amazing transformation photos speak for themselves. Money-savvy Claireaposs biggest purchase was her laminate flooring which cost £. Unbelievably, the rest of the room was transformed simply using wallpaper , paint primer , cupboard paint , and vinyl worktop covering . I wanted to make it modern whilst still keeping the costs down, Claire-Louise said. Iaposd seen on Pinterest that you could use a vinyl wrap on work surfaces. I used DC fix wrap which has held up really well around knives and hot pans. This is a great budget alternative to replacing worktops.  It is tricky when placing the vinyl wrap around the hob and sink but you do get the hang of it with practise. Iaposd recommend buying an extra-large roll in case you make a mistake. We learnt to use a credit card to smooth out any air bubbles and then a filing kne to make sure the material was flush to the wall tiles. For paint, make sure you use wood and furniture paint. They are the first locally transmitted cases in the Chinese capital in more than  days. Six of the seven cases have reportedly been linked to the Xinfadi meat market. The Fengtai district is now under lockdown with residents banned from leaving their homes on  estates. The market has , tenants and will be disinfected after workers there tested positive and the virus was found in the environment, the official Xinhua News Agency said. Two of the first people to be infected had been to the market and a third worked with one of them at a meat research institute, according to Chinese media reports.  to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at mirror email -after the press conference every evening.Another seafood market visited by one of the patients, was also closed for disinfection and sample collection. Chu Junwei, an official of Beijingaposs Fengtai district, said the district was in wartime emergency mode.He added that throat swabs from  people, out of  tested at the districtaposs Xinfadi wholesale market, had tested positive for the new coronavirus, though none of them showed symptoms of COVID-, according to Aljazeera News.Planned reopenings for certain age groups toto schools and nurseries have now been delayed and sports events suspended or cancelled again as military police were sent to the Fengtai district to aposseal it offapos.  Beijing authorities said more than , people at the market will take nucleic acid tests to detect coronavirus infections. China has always insisted that the outbreak began in a so-called wet market in Wuhan, where live animals were being sold.Health authorities in Beijing believe the virus came from an animal in Huanan market, Wuhan. The market was closed by officials a day after the World Health Organisation was informed in December.  But other research has suggested the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak may have started in October - two months earlier than previously thought. Satellite pictures show Wuhan hospital car parks were far busier in October last year than during the same month in . An analysis of the Chinese internet giant Baidu also revealed a spike in aposcoughapos and aposdiarrheaapos searches in October last year. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe coastal town of Lagos is home to a curious mix of locals, drters, bohemians and tourists drawn to the sunny, laid-back Algarve. But even among this community, Christian Brueckner stood out. The German detested the “scruffy hippies”, as he called them, preferring to dress in old tailored suits. He also shunned their drug-fuelled lestyle, at least publicly, saying narcotics made him “lose control”. Brueckner apparently tried to portray himself as a gent, wooing women with his classic good manners. But behind the veneer there was a dark side to him, which remained hidden to even his closest friends. When he first arrived with a girlfriend in tow in , aged , he was already a convicted sex offender in Germany.  He had fled to Portugal after serving a two-year juvenile term for abusing a six-year-old girl in a playground and exposing himself to a nine-year-old girl when he was . And that was not his first brush with the law. Born Christian Fischer in Baia in , he was given up by his birth mother and placed in a children’s home, then adopted by Fritz and Brigitte Brueckner from Bergtheim, Baia. He was convicted of his first burglary in nearby Wuerzburg in , aged .  His adoptive parents sent him to a reform home for delinquent teens after Fritz was seriously injured in a car crash. In , Brueckner got an eight-month suspended juvenile term for multiple thefts and driving without a licence. After serving time for the later sex offences he started his new le in Lagos. He became a regular in the bars and clubs and was often seen at all-night parties in the hippy village of Barao de Sao Joao.He first came to the attention of Portuguese authorities in , when he was arrested following a bar brawl. He was handed a two-month jail term in Evora, near Lisbon, but was freed after a matter of weeks.  By the time he wooed a lonely -year-old English woman newly arrived in Lagos in , he had been in Portugal for almost a decade. As with previous girlfriends, he turned on the charm and played up to his “gentlemanly” image. The woman, now , told the Mirror: “At first I didn’t actually like him that much. I was , he was a couple of years younger. I knew he liked me but I wasn’t interested. But Chris could be very, very charming, very funny and very smooth in the way he talked. “He always dressed nicely, held the door open, that kind of thing. He drove the nice car – the black Jaguar – was very gentlemanly and spoke properly.  “I was alone in Portugal, no family around and a bit lonely. We became friends in the spring of  and that moved on to us becoming romantic. At first it was great.” The Mirror told this week how the woman, who does not want to be named, said he later changed. She claimed he flew into jealous rages, and allegedly smashed her head against a toilet wall in  after she hugged a male pal. She said she still lives in fear of him now. Shortly after their relationship began, Brueckner left his bar job and made money repairing classic cars. The woman, from Berkshire, said: “He liked taking me to the beach in his Jaguar. He didn’t like the town beach in Lagos. It would always be the West coast beaches, the isolated ones.  “He didn’t like lots of crowds. He didn’t like all the tourists in the summer.”She told how he once made her “strange German food” at his home. It is this house, situated on a hill ­overlooking Praia da Luz, that has become the focus of police attention. Brueckner moved out in , after receiving a nine-month prison term for petrol theft – a year before Madeleine McCann disappeared aged three from her family’s holiday apartment in the resort in May . A neighbour who cleaned up the property told last week how she found filthy conditions and bags of wigs and exotic clothes. This came as a surprise to his British ex, who remembered him being “house-proud”. But she also had an explanation for the items found.She said: “Chris loved to dress up, but not in a kinky way. He loved fancy-dress parties, especially Halloween, so he kept all sorts of outfits in the house. “He wasn’t into anything weird with me. We just had a normal sex le.” Despite his previous offences, his ex had no clue he was sexually attracted to young children. Instead, she and her pals in Lagos suspected Brueckner – now in a high-security German prison – had a thing for older women. She said: “There was one lady he used to take out to dinner sometimes, she was a bit older, and he said it was just for company. There was another lady, she was much older. He used to walk her dog and clean her apartment and she gave him money for that.” Months after they split in , Brueckner raped a -year-old woman in her Praia da Luz home. He was handed a seven-year jail term last year but is appealing his conviction.  His ex said Brueckner’s only passion, besides his cars, was making money. She said: “Other people get joy out of films, music, socialising, that sort of thing. But for him,there was no money to be made out of something, then there was no point doing it.” Brueckner was living in a camper van in the Praia da Luz area when Madeleine vanished from the Ocean Club resort. Police had him in their sights within five days and staff at the resort were shown his picture and name to seethey recognised him. But he only became a suspect in  when a caller to the German version of Crimewatch claimed he had hinted in a bar that he knew what had happened to Madeleine. In the intervening decade, Brueckner had regularly moved between Germany and Portugal. His German pals told the Mirror he had two dogs he treated so badly that one of them died. One was a daschund-cross called Mrs Muller, the other a rottweiler called Charlie. He reportedly left them locked inside a kiosk bar for six weeks – with one becoming so malnourished it died.

title: dundee fc james mcpake championship return
story: Premiership managers are plotting their players’to training.But Dundee boss James McPake is still wondering when he’ll get the chance to lay out his Dark Blueprint.Amid continuing uncertainty over when the Championship will get started – and what form it will take – a provisional agreement has reportedly been reached between second-tier clubs to kick off a truncated -game season on October .The prospect of a -week wait until competitive football begins is far from ideal.But McPake reckons Championship clubs are becoming so desperate for a speck of light at the end of the tunnel that even an October start date will be gratefully received.He said: “I have heard bits and pieces but the problem, certainly for me, is that it is not definitive, it is a guide.“That’s why I am finding it tough and why every other manager, player and staff member in football is probably the same.“I am very cautious when I say how unsettling or how bad that is for us as there is a hell of a lot more going on in everyday le that means more than football.“Butthat dateis when we are starting then that will be a bonus for us. It will be a massive plus that we have something to work to.“Every manager will probably tell you the same – we need a date for when we are going to go back.“But as I said, I am cautious because there is an awful lot going on at the moment, from where you can take your kids to when you can go and meet other people.“Everything is changing and I don’t think football will be any dferent.”Reconstruction plans have now been run up the flagpole and ripped back down again more than once.Consensus, as is so often the case in Scottish football, has proved impossible to reach.Meanwhile clubs like Dundee, whose business model means they sit uncomfortably in the Championship, have been left in limbo.It has affected everyone at the club – and their manager is growing tired of the uncertainty.However, McPake is conscious of the wider issues in today’s world, and his annoyance is tempered by realism.He said: “There is frustration but for me that can’t be put on anyone.“There is a frustration in every industry about where we find ourselves.“We have never been in a situation like this before and what that brings is a real level of uncertainty.“We are looking for answers every day. I would be very reluctant to blame that on a single person or organisation as you can see it right across the world at the minute. But yes, it is frustrating.“If you are looking at it purely from a footballing point of view it is really dficult for the players, for the backroom staff and for the fans.“But again there is a bigger picture here in terms of a health crisis.“We have to be guided by the government and the governing bodies in football but it has not been easy.“Everybody is in the same boat really and there are no real answers to what is happening and when we can get back to what is perceived as normal.“It is dficult – there is no other way of putting it.”For as long as the Championship remains without a definitive restart date, many elements of Dundee’s normal business operations will remain on hold. On the football side, that means recruitment and day-to-day work with players.They are crucial to any club’s success.But McPake insists he – and everybody  at Dens Park who is not furloughed – is doing everything he can to ensure as seamless ato action as possible.“I speak to Johna couple of times a week or maybe more but nothing has really changed,” he said. “We are where we are and there is no definitive date to when we can start back. It is not like a normal summer or break in the season like a winter one or international break.“There is always a structure to football and when you are back. The players, staff, everybody knows that but at the moment that has completely gone.“It is everyone’s longest lay-off – we are now getting to the stage where the players have been off the same amount of timethey had a serious injury so that brings its problems physically and mentally.“It is just about trying to get everything right so that when we do get the green light to start back we are in as good a position as possible.”EXCLUSIVE: Ex-Dundee striker Peter MacDonald confirms he’s hanging up his boots and says best day of his career came as a Dark Blues player" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-fc-peter-macdonald-retirement-st-johnstone-rangers embed # secretWJcMNsFIpT" data-secret"WJcMNsFIpT" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite.
